channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: US Gambling Revenue Booms in Q1, Matching Records
item.description: Las Vegas is back, if you trust all the lines out the door at McCarran International Airport. US commercial casinos raked in $11.1 billion last quarter, according to the American Gaming Association, matching their best quarter ever. And both traditional and new-ish sectors of the US gambling industry are seeing the benefits. What happened?
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: May 14
item.description: Check out their pieces on Korean adoptees being brought together by Facebook or fact-checking Modi's India. It's a big trend in the country for couples to gift each other "stock gift cards" in companies like Tesla, Apple, Amazon, and Disney.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: JPMorgan, Wells Fargo, and More to Offer Credit Cards for Consumers Without Credit
item.description: While there's no shortage of finance startups hawking credit-building apps to consumers as young as 13, a massive banking gap persists among adults: The creators of the FICO score estimate that 53 million US adults lack traditional credit scores. Big picture: For decades, a credit score was the golden ticket to a credit card.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: CDC Says Fully Vaccinated People Can Ditch Masks in Most Settings
item.description: Health-care settings, buses/trains, and airplanes are all spaces you'll still have to mask up regardless of vaccine status, but the announcement is sure to push the US even further toward a full-scale reopening.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: 2020's Biggest IPOs Are Getting Smacked in the Markets
item.description: The Renaissance IPO ETF, which holds a number of public companies that IPOed within the last two years, has fallen nearly 30% from its peak in February.   Some of the biggest companies to IPO in 2020 and early 2021 are finding the public markets to be less inviting than a middle school boy’s treehouse.  Bumble: Shares in the dating company dipped below their initial price of $43 yesterday after reporting a mixed bag of earnings this week.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: May 14
item.description: Check out their pieces on Korean adoptees being brought together by Facebook or fact-checking Modi's India. It's a big trend in the country for couples to gift each other "stock gift cards" in companies like Tesla, Apple, Amazon, and Disney.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: 2020's Biggest IPOs Are Getting Smacked in the Markets
item.description: Some of the biggest companies to IPO in 2020 and early 2021 are finding the public markets to be less inviting than a middle school boy’s treehouse. com and mortgage insurer Enact Holdings recently delayed their IPOs because of market volatility. The Renaissance IPO ETF, which holds a number of recently public companies such as Pinterest, Coinbase, Roblox, and Slack, has fallen nearly 30% from its peak in February.  But the drooping share prices of freshly public companies is enough to spook some private firms from taking the IPO plunge.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: The Brew’s Weekly News Quiz: May 14
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: JPMorgan, Wells Fargo, and More to Offer Credit Cards for Consumers Without Credit
item.description: Big picture: For decades, a credit score was the golden ticket to a credit card. Later this year, JPMorgan Chase, US Bancorp, and Wells Fargo will join several other banks in a pilot program offering credit cards to people without credit scores, the WSJ reported.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: CDC Says Fully Vaccinated People Can Ditch Masks in Most Settings
item.description: Health-care settings, buses/trains, and airplanes are all spaces you'll still have to mask up regardless of vaccine status, but the announcement is sure to push the US even further toward a full-scale reopening.
item.author: Matty Merritt

US commercial casinos raked in $11.1 billion last quarter, according to the American Gaming Association, matching their best quarter ever. And both traditional and new-ish sectors of the US gambling industry are seeing the benefits. What happened?

item.title: Ark Invest Dumps Virgin Galactic Shares
item.description: Virgin Galactic was once Lord of the SPACs. In 2019, Palihapitya took Richard Branson’s space flight company public in a SPAC deal before they were cool. Some of Virgin Galactic’s biggest boosters are looking for an escape pod.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: May 13
item.description: Those who are least engaged are very comfortable working from home.” (Vice) It’s not like he has anything riding on the office market…Read: How the personal computer broke the human body.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Bill Ackman’s Pershing Square Snaps Up 6% of Domino’s
item.description: Zoom out: This pizza party has been rocking for years.  Ackman said that he’s had his eye on Domino’s for a while, specifically watching how the company does its own delivery in the DoorDash-era.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Musk Says Tesla Will Suspend Bitcoin Payments for Its Cars
item.description: Zoom out: Tesla still has more than $1 billion in bitcoin holdings and Musk said he wouldn't sell any more. Maybe he was too busy rehearsing for SNL?
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Inflation Is Rising Because the Economy Is Weird
item.description: Is this rapid inflation growth temporary? Which brings us to the question raging among economists.  So, many officials are betting that once the economy irons out the wrinkles, price growth will settle down to more typical levels. US consumer prices rose 4.2% in April from a year ago, up from the 2.6% gain in March and more than economists expected. When goodbye hugs make a comeback and the rate of inflation hits its highest level in almost 13 years. “This number was well above what I and outside forecasters expected.”
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Inflation Is Rising Because the Economy Is Weird
item.description: Is this rapid inflation growth temporary? Which brings us to the question raging among economists.  So, many officials are betting that once the economy irons out the wrinkles, price growth will settle down to more typical levels. US consumer prices rose 4.2% in April from a year ago, up from the 2.6% gain in March and more than economists expected. May’s numbers will better help policymakers understand whether inflation is less “transitory” than it appears to be. “This number was well above what I and outside forecasters expected.”
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: US Gambling Revenue Booms in Q1 to Match Record
item.description: Las Vegas is back, if you trust all the lines out the door at McCarran International Airport. US commercial casinos raked in $11.1 billion last quarter, according to the American Gaming Association, matching their best quarter ever.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Reader Q&A: Is Inflation Bad for Stocks?
item.description: Brew's A: Prices on everything from cereal to ride-hailing services are rising right now, and some investors are getting antsy about inflation, or the rate at which the prices of goods and services rise.  At its last reading in April, the consumer price index (CPI), an indicator of the cost for a "basket" of typical consumer goods and services, was up 2.6% over the preceding 12 months.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: May 12
item.description: (Eater)  Read: Your least favorite gross viral food videos are all connected to one guy. FWIW, fellow mayoral candidate Shaun Donovan, who was the former Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, guessed $100,000.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: YouTube Shorts Sets Up $100M Creators Fund
item.description: To support its short-form video product, Shorts, YouTube is setting up a $100 million fund to lure creators away from other platforms, such as TikTok. OK, mostly from TikTok. Shorts? And TikTok recently expanded its fund for US creators to $1 billion over three years.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: The Gas Shortages Are Here
item.description: Zoom out: Gas prices are at their highest level since 2014, per AAA.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: New Cryptocurrency Trading Platform Bullish Takes on Decentralized Finance
item.description: one's own blockchain to cut out the market makers, which traditionally execute a transaction and profit on the difference between the price you paid and how much they actually made the trade for, aka the "spread." The other reason's a bit simpler…Crypto is the new Snack Pack puddingTrading on big-time crypto exchanges surged from less than $100 billion in April 2020 to $1.7 trillion last month, per data from The Block Crypto. The market ballooned from about $15 billion at the start of the year to $65 billion currently, per JPMorgan.  Bullish will run on Block.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: The Gas Shortages Are Here
item.description: Zoom out: Gas prices are at their highest level since 2014, per AAA.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: New Cryptocurrency Trading Platform Bullish Takes on Decentralized Finance
item.description: The other reason's a bit simpler…Crypto is the new Snack Pack puddingTrading on big-time crypto exchanges surged from less than $100 billion in April 2020 to $1.7 trillion last month, per data from The Block Crypto. The market ballooned from about $15 billion at the start of the year to $65 billion currently, per JPMorgan.  Bullish will run on Block. Meet Bullish Global, which will open later this year with $10 billion of crypto assets pre-loaded and ready to trade, including 164,000 bitcoins.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: NBC Says it Won't Air Golden Globes in 2022
item.description: The context: The HFPA, an 87-member organization that votes on TV and movie awards, was the focus of a February report in the LA Times that found the group had zero Black members and was doing sketchy things, like flying to lavish parties for Emily in Paris—a series that received two Golden Globe nominations despite low critical approval.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: May 11
item.description: (New Yorker)  Read: A juicy profile of Robinhood and its promise to democratize investing.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Attorneys General Ask Facebook to Drop Plans for Instagram for Kids
item.description: Yesterday, a group of 44 attorneys general asked Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg to ditch plans to develop an Instagram platform for children younger than 13, the current age cutoff for FB services. Bottom line: Just because you can make a product for kids doesn't mean you should."
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: DarkSide, the Group Behind the Colonial Pipeline Hack, Speaks Out
item.description: Can't fix a pipeline problem overnightYesterday, the pipeline's operator, Colonial, said it's hoping to bring the full system back online by the end of the week. But if the shutdown takes longer than expected to resolve, GasBuddy analysts predict gas prices could rise more than a few cents. so far.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Restaurants Struggling to Hire Staff as Lockdowns Lift
item.description: Restaurants have elevated sanitation requirements, plenty of food supply chain issues, and an average annual salary of only $21,470 to serve brunch crowds that have been locked inside for a year. demand for eating out will only increase over the summer, so restaurant chains are raising pay and finding other creative methods to recruit workers. It appears that the restaurant industry in particular just isn't all that attractive for people looking for work.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: From Cheese to Ubers, Prices Are Rising
item.description: Commodities: Prices of copper, steel, and Catan fan-favorite resource lumber have all soared to record highs, causing a corresponding price increase in end products, like houses. Rideshare: If you thought an Uber/Lyft to Malibu was expensive before the pandemic...
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: NBC Says it Won't Air Golden Globes in 2022
item.description: The context: The HFPA, an 87-member organization that votes on TV and movie awards, was the focus of a February report in the LA Times that found the group had zero Black members and was doing sketchy things, like flying to lavish parties for Emily in Paris—a series that received two Golden Globe nominations despite low critic approval across the board.
item.author: Matty Merritt
